summary: This is a letter from defense attorney Bruce Barket to Judge Kenneth K. Karas requesting an evidentiary hearing regarding the government's failure to preserve video surveillance footage from the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) that captured the hallway outside the cell shared by Nicholas Tartaglione and Jeffrey Epstein during Epstein's suicide attempt on July 23, 2019. The letter argues the footage would have been exculpatory for Tartaglione and criticizes the government's inconsistent explanations for its destruction.

persons.name: Nicholas Tartaglione
persons.context: Defendant in a capital case who shared a cell with Jeffrey Epstein at the MCC during Epstein's suicide attempt. His defense maintains he tried to help Epstein and called for guards.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Inmate who attempted suicide in his MCC cell on July 23, 2019, while sharing it with Tartaglione. He was later found dead in a different cell on August 10, 2019.

persons.name: Bruce Barket
persons.context: Attorney for Nicholas Tartaglione who authored this letter to Judge Karas requesting an evidentiary hearing about the destroyed surveillance video.

persons.name: Kenneth K. Karas
persons.context: Judge presiding over the case United States v. Nicholas Tartaglione to whom this request for an evidentiary hearing is addressed.

persons.name: Adam Johnson
persons.context: BOP counsel who responded to the defense's July 25, 2019, video preservation request, stating he had asked appropriate staff to preserve the footage.

persons.name: Leisenring
persons.context: Defense counsel who sent the initial video preservation request email to Adam Johnson on July 25, 2019.

connections.description: Shared a cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center at the time of Epstein's suicide attempt in July 2019.
Bruce Barket is the defense attorney representing Nicholas Tartaglione in his capital case.
Adam Johnson, as BOP counsel, directed MCC staff to preserve the surveillance video per the defense's request.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein Suicide Attempt at MCC
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein attempted to commit suicide in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center during the early morning hours, while sharing the cell with Nicholas Tartaglione.

events.title: Defense Video Preservation Request
events.description: Defense counsel Leisenring sent an email to BOP's Adam Johnson formally requesting preservation of video surveillance footage from the hallway outside Tartaglione's cell from July 22-23, 2019.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein Found Dead
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in a different cell at the MCC, having been moved after his July suicide attempt.

events.title: Court Proceedings on Missing Video
events.description: During court proceedings, defense advised the court the video had been destroyed despite the preservation request. Government stated it was awaiting further information from BOP.

events.title: Government Explains Video Loss
events.description: Government informed the court that MCC staff inadvertently preserved video from the wrong tier, and the backup system housing the requested video no longer existed due to technical errors since at least August 2019.

locations: Southern District of New York, 300 Quarropas Street, White Plains, NY 10601
keyFacts: Video surveillance footage from the MCC hallway outside the cell shared by Nicholas Tartaglione and Jeffrey Epstein during Epstein's July 23, 2019, suicide attempt was destroyed despite a formal preservation request from the defense.
The defense argues the lost video was exculpatory and would have shown Tartaglione trying to help Epstein and calling for guards, which could serve as mitigating evidence in his capital case.

The government provided inconsistent accounts of the video's status, initially saying it was preserved and would be provided, then stating it was lost due to MCC staff preserving footage from the wrong tier and a failed backup system.
The defense is requesting a court-ordered evidentiary hearing to determine how and why the video was destroyed, who was responsible, and whether the government acted in bad faith.
